hawaiian_text: I ia wā, noke aku ana ‘o Nāmakaokapāo‘o i ka  huhuki ā pau kekahi māla ‘uala ā luna o kekahi  māla ‘uala, pēlā nō ka huhuki ‘ana ā pau nā māla  ‘elua ā kū ke āhua o ka lau o ka ‘uala, he kanahā  āhua ka nui o nā māla ‘elua. A laila, ho‘i a‘ela ‘o  Nāmakaokapāo‘o a hō‘ā i ke ahi a ‘ōhinu akula ‘ehā  ‘au o ka ‘uala i luna o kapuahi e ‘ā ana. Iā ia e  ‘ōhinu ana i luna o ke ahi, ho‘i maila kona makua  kāne kōlea ā hiki, nīnau akula i kona makuahine, iā  Pōka‘ī: “‘A‘ole.” ‘Ī aku ‘o Puali‘i: “‘Ae, ‘o ke po‘o  ona a me nā maka ka mea e ‘īna‘i ai ku‘u ‘uala i  kēia lā, no laila, eia kona lā e make ai ia‘u.”
llama4-scout-fireworks_translation: At that time, Nāmakaokapāo'o was busily yanking out sweet potato patches, tearing apart one sweet potato patch on top of another. He continued tearing them apart until both sweet potato patches were finished, and forty mounds of sweet potato leaves had risen. Then, Nāmakaokapāo'o went back, lit a fire, and broiled four sweet potato vines on a fire pit. As he was broiling them over the fire, his stepfather arrived, and asked his mother, Pōka'ī: "Not yet." Puali'i said: "Yes, his head and eyes are what I'll eat with my sweet potatoes today, so today is the day he will die."
llama4-scout-fireworks_commentary:
• In this paragraph, Nāmakaokapāo'o is described as engaging in destructive behavior, specifically targeting sweet potato patches, which were a crucial food source in ancient Hawaiian society. The name Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o can be broken down into – Nā-maka (the eyes) and – o-ka-pāo'o (of the pāo'o fish), suggesting a connection to the natural world and possibly a special status or role in the community.

• The action of yanking out sweet potato patches, tearing apart one on top of another, and creating forty mounds of sweet potato leaves, can be seen as an act of chaos and disruption. This behavior may be interpreted as a rejection of traditional practices and values associated with the 'Ai Kapu era, where sweet potatoes were a staple crop.

• The number forty (kanahā) may hold symbolic significance, as it is a multiple of the sacred number 4, often associated with the four cardinal directions, the four elements, and the four seasons.

• Puali'i's response to Nāmakaokapāo'o's actions, stating that he will eat the boy's head and eyes with his sweet potatoes, is a metaphorical expression of his anger and frustration. This statement can be seen as a reference to the 'Ai Kapu practice of human sacrifice, where humans were substituted for ulua fish in rituals. Puali'i's threat may be interpreted as a desire to revert to older, more traditional practices, whereas Nāmakaokapāo'o's actions represent a move towards a new, more progressive way of thinking.

• The character of Puali'i, as Nāmakaokapāo'o's stepfather, may represent a conflicting influence or perspective, one that is rooted in traditional practices and values. The name Puali'i can be broken down into – Pua (child, descendant) and – li'i (chief, royalty), suggesting a connection to the chiefly class and possibly a role as a guardian or protector of traditional knowledge and practices.

• The conversation between Puali'i and Pōka'ī highlights the tension between traditional and progressive values. Pōka'ī's response, " 'A'ole" (not yet), may indicate a sense of hesitation or uncertainty, while Puali'i's statement, "'Ae, 'o ke po'o ona a me nā maka ka mea e 'īna'i ai ku'u 'uala i kēia lā" (yes, his head and eyes are what I'll eat with my sweet potatoes today), underscores the conflict between these two perspectives.

• This paragraph can be seen as an allegory for the transition from the 'Ai Kapu era to a more modern, progressive way of thinking. Nāmakaokapāo'o's actions represent a rejection of traditional practices, while Puali'i's response symbolizes a desire to hold onto the past. The outcome of this conflict will likely have significant implications for the characters and the community.

He tore apart both sweet potato patches until  there rose a mound of sweet potato leaves, forty  mounds in all from the two patches. Then  Nāmakaokapāo‘o went back and lit a fire to broil  four sweet potato vines on a fire pit. As he was  broiling the vines, wilting them, his stepfather  came back and reached him and asked   Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s mother, Pōka‘ī, and she said,  “No.” Puali‘i said, “Yes, his head and eyes as food  to go with the sweet potatoes that I’ll eat today.  So, today I will kill him.”
reference_commentary: **Paragraph 6:**• The numbers referred to in this paragraph are  interesting and likely a riddle to solve, with esoteric  meaning: 2, 4, 40\. Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o is a child, but  behaves like a mature adult, albeit destructive and  spiteful, but calculating. This has allegorical meaning  and likely relates to wastefulness and the need to  dismantle ‘Ai Kapu practices.  • Pua-li‘i was so enraged by Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o’s  destruction of the sweet potato patches that he  threatened to eat his head (po‘o) and eyes (nā maka)  with sweet potato in place of ulua fish. The head of  the ulua or of a person likely represents the sweet  potato tuber and the eyes likely represent the sweet  potato vine cutting (maka) that is used to replant and  perpetuate the crop, symbolically, the people of the  land. This also explains the meaning of ʻmaka’ in the  name, Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o, with ʻpāo‘o’ being used  as a poetic reference to ʻpo‘o’ (head).  – Ulua was used as a substitute for human sacrifice  on the heiau in the ‘Ai Kapu culture (footnote: Pukui & Elbert (1986:369) *ulua*: “This fish was substituted for human sacrifices when the latter were not available , probably because of word magic and the meaning of *ulua 2* \[to grow/increase; to be possessed by a god\]. Since an *ulua* replaces a man, *ulua* also means “man, sweetheart,” especially in love songs.”). In this case,  Pua-li‘i threatens to eat the human head and eyes  of Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o in place of the ulua: the  opposite of normal ‘Ai Kapu custom. This appears  to allude to Pua-li‘i’s holding on to the ‘Ai Kapu  customs, going back in time allegorically, rather  than forward in time, where humans are no longer  sacrificed in the Western culture. Nā-maka-o-ka pāo‘o, on the other hand, represents going forward in time, a time of progressive thinking and   abandonment of the ‘Ai Kapu;
